description: The next step in your learning once you understand the simple traffic light example provided in the XOD documentation. Updated for XOD 0.32.1; added mutex, bus, and jumper examples.
name: traffic-light-advanced

HkXh1aAVf.content:
Introduction:
* A simple state machine that cycles through 3 lights, turning on only one at a time and loop back to repeat.
* Note that a defer node should usually follow the boot node so system stabalizes before starting any code. Here we reuse the same defer node for boot and to allow the program to loop.

* see one-light to see how we control the lights.

@/0-traffic-simple.description: Review of simple traffic light for only one direction.

r1Kdu3R4z.content:
Attempt #1:
* Realize that we don't need to directly control Red lights, we just need red light on if any green or yellow lights are on for other directions.
* Turn  on green light for NS, then turn off green & turn on yellow, then turn off yellow and move to EW green light.

* With this structure, we cannot encapsulate lights for each direction because we need communication between lights in each direction (cross-connection of OR nodes)
* Let's try again using select statements. Open 2-traffic-select-flat

@/1-traffic-delay-bad.description: Traffic light example in one node using delay timers and "or" nodes.

S1d2SjC4G.content: When timer is active, switch lights to non-default; switch back to default when Done. Green->Yellow transition can leave Red off.

SklAK2ANM.content:
Attempt#2:
* Select will default to S2 (right-most) value, so we set Red to default on while Yellow & Green default off.
* Cycle starts with all Red lights, then we select non-default value for NS Red & Green, then switch Green back to default & select non-default value for Yellow (Red does not need to change yet), then switch Yellow & Red back to default & proceed to EW lights.

* It is ugly, but we achieved encapsulation, so we can take delays, selects, and outputs for lights in each direction and make them a new node. The node needs a start pulse and port #s for Red/Yellow/Green LEDs as well as an output pulse. Open 3-traffic-select to see how it works.

@/2-traffic-select-flat.description: Traffic light example in one node using delay timers and select nodes.

rJRKihRNz.content:
Attempt#3:
* Nice clean main node
* signal-select encapsulates R/Y/G lights for each direction. Open signal-select for next step

@/3-traffic-select.description: Traffic light main example with signal for each direction encapsulated in its own node using select nodes.

r1f8a3RVM.content:
Attempt#4:
* Back to delay without Select. Replace cascading ORs with a single NOR.
* Much cleaner than selects and still provides encapsulation.
* Open 5-traffic-delay to see the encapsulation.

@/4-traffic-delay-flat.description: Traffic light example in one node using delay timers and nor gate for Red

B1Q1C2REG.content:
Attempt#5:
* Same clean main node we had with select statements
* See signal-delay for encapsulated code

@/5-traffic-delay.description: Traffic light main example with signal for each direction encapsulated in its own node using delay timers.

HJ3zZIlSM.content:
Attempt#6:
* Let's add a turn signl for NS traffic. Assuming we only want to cycle the turn signal while someone is waiting to turn, we need a way to provide an if/then condition for flow-control. With the branch node, when the pulse comes into TRIG, it will exit either the True or False port, depending on whether GATE is True or False.
* Here we have a button node to represent the car sensor that would be in the road (for us probably just a button). If the sensor is active, we will cycle the left-turn signal.
* Another "any" node will join the two code branches back together and then loop back to restart the full cycle

* Want EW to have a longer green light than NS traffic? Then you will have to add an input pin to signal-delay to specify time to stay green and link that to the timer for green delay.

* What if we want NS to stay green until there is traffic in the EW (or NS turn) lanes? One option would be to replace the delay node for green with a flip-flop and add another pulse-input (perhaps labeled Cont) to indicate when it is time to continue. For NS signal, Cont would be tied to the traffic sensor for EW traffic (probably OR'd with the turn sensor). For EW signal (and NS turn), we would include a delay node in Main to trigger Cont. Note that you will also need to add a timer for the NS signal so it doesn't trigger immediately if there is EW or turn traffic. (Hint: You can feed a boolean value to a pulse input. It will pulse when the boolean turns True. You will want to Cont if timer-ACT is False and traffic sensor is True.) See if you can work out a solution yourself before proceding to 7-traffic-continue..

@/6-traffic-turn.description: Adding a turn signal to your 2-way traffic light.

rkW_GMNHf.content:
Variable Green light:
* Quite a bit more complicated, but also a lot more powerful.
* The NS lanes will have a green light for the specified minimum time, and it will stay green after that until EW or NS turn traffic sensors are triggered. Note that we don't use the DONE pin for NS Green delay now; we use the AND node instead.
* Once NS light is red, we will check EW sensor; if active, we will cycle that light.
* Once EW is red (or if EW sensor was not active), we will check NS turn sensor & cycle that light if it is active.
* Once NS turn light is red (or if NS turn sensor was not active), we will cycle back to the beginning.
* Note that since green delay was pulled out of the signal node, we automatically have the option to specify different green times for each light. We would still need to add a pin for yellow delay if we wanted that different for each direction.
* Note how EW and NST have the same functionality, so I have arranged the nodes for each in the same way to make this more obvious. One might even note that there is good encasulation for these, so a new node could be created to encapsulate the any, branch, delay, signal, and sensor. Since the NS light needs to know when sensors are active, you will need to include an output pin for it (or optionally leave them out of the new node).
See signal-cont for new encapsulation code.

@/7-traffic-continue.description: No cheating...try to figure out the challenge in 6-traffic-turn on your own

rkc-Va6_ckU.content:
Adding Mutex locking.
* Our main code doesn't change very much. All we've done is add a MUX pin to the signal patch.
* We have to pass the same mutex to all the signal patches so they can share the same lock and only allow one to be active at a time.

Bus nodes to cleanup messy wiring.

* In order to eliminate some of the wires cutting across or back up the patch, we've replaced some of those wires with to-bus and from-bus nodes. These are the triangle nodes near the bottom and top of the patch.
* The bus nodes are basically invisible wires and can be used the same as wires.
* You can quickly replace a wire with a to/from bus pair by clicking the wire and hitting "b" to convert it to bus nodes.
* You can also manually add to-bus or from-bus nodes.
* Nodes with the same label will be linked together and share the same data. You can only have one to-bus per label because each wire can only have one value. You can have multiple from-bus nodes to create copies of the data for multiple inputs (and/or run multiple wires from a single from-bus node).
* For the mutex, we create a single MUX, then pass it to each signal node by linking directly, daisy-chaining through another node (which requires the node to pass the MUX to an output pin), and using bus nodes. All are equally valid and it is just a matter of preference and/or whatever is cleaner for a particular patch.
* Note that it is also possible to over-use bus nodes. Adding more bus pairs makes it harder to find the matching bus for any bus node you are trying to trace.

Note that to the right of each EW & NST Green delay node there is a short wire with pins top & bottom. This is a jumper and can be added to your patch just like any node. All it does is allow you to force a wire to route through a particular spot to clean things up. Without these jumper wires, the wire between any & branch would run through the delay node instead of around it. Unfortunately, it behaves like a node and output pins must link to the top of the jumper and input pins to the bottom, so it is not very useful for routing wires from the bottom back to the top of the patch.

See signal-cont-mutex for how the MUX is actually used.

SJXSeaR4z.content:
Introduction, encapsulation:
* On entry, we trigger a delay timer. As long as the timer is ACT, we turn on the light tied to this port.
* Note the defer-pulse node before we exit. This is to make sure the system stabalizes with the light off before we continue. It is not always needed depending on what you are doing, but things sometimes become unstable without it.

* This works if we only need 1 light on at a time
* It does not work if we need lights for 2 directions of traffic; one must stay Red while the other direction is cycling through Green/Yellow.

* See 1-traffic-delay-bad for a 1st attempt to control a traffic signal for 2 directions.

@/one-light.description: A simle node to turn one light on for a set time

S1YtVfESM.content:
Variable green light:
* Here you can see how the green delay timer has been replaced by a flip-flop to remember state. The start pulse no longer travels from green through the rest of the cycle; we just get stuck on green.

* Notice the Cont pulse must reset the flip-flop for green and start the timer for yellow.

* Once the yellow timer expires, we pass the pulse through as before.

*
* Bonus question. This code has a MAJOR bug. If one of the sensors is triggered when we do not have a green for NS traffic, the NS light still "continues" its cycle, giving green lights for more than one direction -- a VERY bad thing for a traffic light. How can we use the 'gate' node to ignore the continue pulse if the light is not green? See signal-cont-gate for one solution.

@/signal-cont.description: Signal lights for one direction with a pin to continue from green instead of a timer.

ry3hiwc18.content:
Don't continue to yellow light if not green
* This is the same as signal-cont, except the Cont pulse is filtered by the gate node.
* The defer node is needed since a loop has been created.when we link to flip-flop-RST.
* If green light is NOT active (i.e. flip-flop-MEM is false), then gate is disabled and Cont pulse is ignored.

Avoid possible split-pulse bugs like this:
* Mutex is a locking mechanism that can be used to guarantee we never have green lights in more than one direction.
* See 8-traffic-mutex for a demonstration.

BkBJ8O9y8.content:
Using MUTEX to guarantee only one green light at a time:
* Mutex is a lock/flag mechanic that allows you to guarantee that muitliple events are not happening at the same time. Each mutex (MUX) can only have one lock, which can only be held by one mutex-* node at a time.
* By using the same MUX for lights in each direction, we guarantee that only one direction can be non-green at any time. Worst-case, we lose our pulse and all lights stay red (causing a traffic jam, but avoiding fatal crashes).
* The bottom half of this node is much the same as before, but now all action pulses are filtered through the mutex node.
* If we are trying to start a light cycle, we first need to aquire a lock; only start cycle if we succeed.
* If we are trying to continue, we must already have an active lock (mutex-gate-IN is passed to mutex-gate-OUT only if lock is active).
* This node is done only after mutex has been Released.
* Since it is possible to force the release of a lock from another node, the mutex-gate-RLSd pin should probably get tied to flip-flop-RST and delay-RST just in case...
* There are other mutex nodes providing additional options/functionality.

Style notes:
* The MUX' output isn't really needed, but it is generally good practice to make it easier to share a single mutex between nodes. It is labled MUX' only because we cannot duplicate pin names and MUX is already taken for the input pin.
* The input pins could be rearanged to reduce cross-over wires, but that should be balanced with providing a reasonable order for pins when using the patch (or compatibility with similar nodes or older versions of the current node).
* As you can see, it is not a requirement that input pins be at the top and output pins be at the bottom, but it is generally a good idea to keep them there so they are easier to find/identify. Moving them to the bottom here would pass the wires through multiple nodes making the patch messier. Bus nodes could be used to move them to the bottom without wires passing through nodes. Personally, I would work harder to move them to the bottom if they were data pins rather than just a pass-through value and Done.
* In this case, MUX' could be moved to the lower-left and wired directly to the MUX input pin rather than the mutex-gate. Done could be moved to the lower-right and a jumper used to route wire around delay node rather than through it.
* In general, good style is a personal preference, but it is obviously easier to trace wires that don't pass through other nodes. If wires do pass through nodes, at least make sure they don't pass directly through pins they are not wired to.
* If wires pass between adjacent nodes, moving the nodes at least one space apart can make the wires much easier to see/trace.

I hope this tutorial has been helpful. Good luck as you continue learning and developing your own projects. It can get frustrating at times, but don't forget to have fun!

HJaN0hA4z.content:
Attempt#5, encapsulation:
* Much cleaner than encapsulation with select statements
* Now that we have signals cleanly encapsulated, let's explore how easy it is to add more in 6-traffic-turn

@/signal-delay.description: Signal lights for one direction using delay timers.

BJZ4FD5k8.content: Note: This Start node is only this far to the right so that it appears to the right of all 3 port inputs when used in a patch.

H1KtIi0NM.content: When timer is active, switch lights to non-default; switch back to default when Done. Green->Yellow transition can leave Red off.

S1_L22C4G.content:
Attempt#3, additional insights
* Select for Yellow & Green are just giving us the state of delay-ACT, so are not really needed.

* Here is where I realized I was an idiot. We do not need to know the state of Yellow and Green lights for other directions (all the cross-connects that prevented encapsulation). All we need to know is that this Red light is on unless this Yellow or Green light is on (an OR followed by NOT, or simply a NOR).

* Proceed to 4-traffic-delay-flat for next attempt

@/signal-select.description: Signal lights for one direction using select nodes.

HJjz6Y04f.description: Run through a green, yellow, red cycle of light. Default to red.
HJjz6Y04f.label: Start
